About
Hello!!! We work on developing artificially intelligent systems that are able to reason about the visual world. Our research brings together the fields of computer vision, machine learning, human-computer interaction as well as fairness, accountability and transparency. We focus on three primary areas of exploration. The first is developing the fundamental perception building blocks of visual recognition, such as object detection, image parsing or human activity recognition. The second is designing human-machine interaction paradigms to enable computer vision systems to effectively learn from and collaborate with humans, including but not limited to studying the interplay between computer vision and natural language. The third is ensuring the fairness of the vision systems with respect to people of all backgrounds by improving dataset design, algorithmic methodology and model interpretability.

News
  • May 2020: Olga Russakovsky is awarded the CRA-WP Anita Borg Early Career Award (BECA). "The annual award is given to a woman in computer science and/or engineering who has made significant research contributions in computer science and/or engineering and has also contributed to the profession, especially in outreach to women."
  • April 2020: Our work ViBE: A Tool for Measuring and Mitigating Bias in Image Datasets by Angelina Wang, Arvind Narayanan, Olga Russakovsky is available on arxiv; code is also available.
  • April 2020: Our work Take the Scenic Route: Improving Generalization in Vision-and-Language Navigation (by Felix Yu, Zhiwei Deng, Karthik Narasimhan, Olga Russakovsky) is accepted to the CVPR 2020 Visual Learning with Limited Labels workshop. (Hope everyone's staying safe out there!)
  • February 2020: Our work "Towards Fairness in Visual Recognition: Effective Strategies for Bias Mitigation" (by Zeyu Wang, Klint Qinami, Yannis Karakozis, Kyle Genova, Prem Nair, Kenji Hata, Olga Russakovsky) is accepted to CVPR 2020.
  • December 2019: Our work "Towards Fairer Datasets: Filtering and Balancing the Distribution of the People Subtree in the ImageNet Hierarchy" (by Kaiyu Yang, Klint Qinami, Li Fei-Fei, Jia Deng, Olga Russakovsky) is accepted to FAT* 2020. Read about it in Wired: AI Is Biased. Here's How Scientists Are Trying to Fix It
  • December 2019: Some recent work available on arxiv:
    1. "Towards Fairness in Visual Recognition: Effective Strategies for Bias Mitigation" by Zeyu Wang, Klint Qinami, Yannis Karakozis, Kyle Genova, Prem Nair, Kenji Hata and Olga Russakovsky
    2. "Compositional Temporal Visual Grounding of Natural Language Event Descriptions" by Jonathan Stroud, Ryan McCaffrey, Rada Mihalcea, Jia Deng and Olga Russakovsky
    3. "CornerNet-Lite: Efficient Keypoint Based Object Detection" by Hei Law, Yun Teng, Olga Russakovsky and Jia Deng
  • November 2019: Read about our new research initiative on diversifying the AI workforce together with AI4ALL.
  • November 2019: Our work on "Fairness in Online Advertisement via Symmetric Auctions" (by Meryem Essaidi, S. Matthew Weinberg and Olga Russakovsky) is accepted to the WINE 2019 poster session.
  • August 2019: Learn about the second iteration of our Princeton AI4ALL summer camp from the Princeton School of Engineering news or from the Education Week newspaper
  • July 2019: Two papers accepted to ICCV 2019
    1. "Human Uncertainty Makes Classification More Robust" by Josh Peterson, Ruairidh Battleday, Tom Griffiths and Olga Russakovsky
    2. "SpatialSense: An Adversarially Crowdsourced Benchmark for Spatial Relation Recognition" by Kaiyu Yang, Olga Russakovsky and Jia Deng
  • June 2019: Congratulations to Berthy Feng and Yannis Karakozis on the "Sigma Xi Book Award for Outstanding Undergraduate Research"
